_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Safety Commitments



World Class Distribution, Daytona Beach, Florida is complying with OSHA Process Safety Management Standard(called Process safety Management or PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal regulations (CFR) 1910.119 and EPAs risk Management Program regulations(called RMP), title 40 CFR Part 68 to deal with Risk involved with the storage, handling, and processing of hazardous chemicals. In this way we promote overall plant, worker and public Safety. These programs enable our facility to prevent the occurance and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illness and avoid physical property damage.

Our safety program are applied to any activity involving hazardous chemicals including any use storage, manufacturing handling or the on-sitemovement of such chemicals or combinations of these activities any group of vessels which are interconnected, and separate vessals which are located such that a hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release shall be considered a single process. Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on rules, procedures and practices which govern individual processes activities or pieces of equipment. These rules are dtailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the Facility.



Description of ammonia refrigeration Process



The ammonia refrigeration system uses roughly about 16,00lbs of ammonia. The majority of the system is located in the engine room including vessels, and compressors. The condensor is mounted on the engine room roof and all evaporators are located in their respective spiral freezers.



The facility uses approximently 16,000lbs of ammonia as a refrigerant within a closed system. The system consiting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical sta

tes (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for process and storage areas.



The compressors pull the low pressure ammonia vapor from the pump receivers where it is compressed into a high pressure vapor. the vapor is then piped to the condensor where the ammonia is converted back to high pressure liquid and recycled to the high pressure receiver. The auto purger periodiclly purges the system of non-condensibles collected in the high pressure receiver and condensors.



Description of worst case scenario



To prevent accidental release of ammonia, World Class Distribution, Daytona Beach, Florida complies with OSHA PSM standard 29CFR 1910.119, EPA RM program regulations in 40CFR Part 68, ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 standard for equipment design and installation of ammonia mechanicalrefrigeration systems.

Failure of the high pressure receiver containing 7,011 lbs of ammonia resulting in a 10 minute release. Under worst case weather conditions, ammonia could travel 1.0 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public, This scenario is unlikely for the following reasons: worst case weather conditions are uncommon: the vessel id enclosed in a building that could withstand and help to contain such a release: Industry standards for the manufacture and quality control of pressure vessels: The accident prevention program in place at the facility including the Mechanical integrity program for regular maintenance inspection and testing and replacement of equipment if necessary installed ammonia sensors in the system to warn of leaks alarms and the auto dialing system in place to warn operating personel of process upsets: and the emergency response plan and equipment in place at the facility.



Description of Alternative case scenario



The alternative release for ammonia involves a broken cndensor tube venting to the atmosphere. According to the EPA in their RMP off si

te consequences analysis (OCA) guidance (ref table) the scenario involves the release of 5,400lbs of ammonia in a gaseous form over 10 minutes. The pressure in the condensor is about 154psi. Under neutral weather conditions, Class D atmospheric stability and wind speed of 3.0 m/s,the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L of ammonia is.20 mile radius.



Description of accidental release prevention program



To prevent accidental release of ammonia, World Class Distribution, Daytona Beach Florida complies with OSHA PSM standards 29CFR 1910.119 EPA RM Program regulations in 40 CFR Part 68, ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 standard for equipment, design, and installation of ammonia Mechanical refrigeration systems.





5 - Year Accident History



There is no 5 year accident history





Description of Emergency Response Program



This Facility emergency response program is based on the OSHA requirements for Emergency Action Plans (29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119) and Hazwoper (29CFR 1910.120 we have trained employees for emergency response and maintain a written emergency response plan. This plan is coordinated with the local emergency planning commitee and the local fire department. We conduct annual drils for implamentation of the Emenrgency response plan at the facility with the participatation of the LEPC and the Fire Department.
